;;栖息在树桩上的北方斑鸮
;

;加拿大内阁部长们拒绝了该国环境部长;拯救濒临灭绝的猫头鹰< /a>;，让人对该物种在未来几年的生存产生怀疑。

;
;

;;相关：;;“我看到的都是鬼魂”：加拿大最后一只斑点猫头鹰为生存而战时的恐惧和愤怒;

;
;

;荒野委员会环境倡导小组;周三宣布;，联邦部长们拒绝了环境部长提交的保护北方斑点猫头鹰紧急命令的请求;Steven Guilbeault;。

;

;荒野委员会多年来一直游说联邦政府进行干预斑点猫头鹰栖息地遭到破坏。

;

;2023 年 2 月，Guilbeault ;说; ;斑点猫头鹰正面临“对其生存的迫在眉睫的威胁”;，并告诉环保组织他将建议采取紧急措施为了阻止其在不列颠哥伦比亚省的栖息地受到进一步破坏。

;

;Guilbeault 得出的结论是，必须停止在 Spô'zêm 民族领土的某个地区（包括 Spuzzum 和 Utzlius 流域）以及另外 2,500 公顷的区域进行伐木活动（6,200 英亩）的森林栖息地面临砍伐风险。

;

;为了使紧急命令生效，联邦内阁在与受影响的原住民协商后必须接受吉尔博的建议。

;

; >;

;然而，在拖延了八个月之后，执政的自由党的其他内阁成员，宣扬了他们对生物多样性保护的承诺，拒绝了该命令。

;

;在西南部工业伐木之前不列颠哥伦比亚省的原始森林里有近1000只斑点猫头鹰。现在，只剩下;一只野生猫头鹰< /a>;.去年秋天放生的两只圈养猫头鹰于五月被发现死亡。今年早些时候，又有两只人工饲养的猫头鹰被释放到野外。

;

;生物学家告诉《卫报》，只要对关键栖息地（所有这些都是古老的森林）提供足够的保护，该物种就可以恢复。

;

; p>;

;由环境法慈善机构 Ecojustice 代表的荒野委员会将于 10 月 18 日出庭，以确定 Guilbeault 延迟八个月向内阁推荐这项紧急命令是否符合联邦法案的要求 ;《濒危物种法案》;。

;

;“自一月份以来，法律要求部长推荐一项紧急命令，”生态正义律师安德拉·阿泽维多在一份声明中说。 “相反，部长花了几个月的时间与[不列颠哥伦比亚省]‘接触’，而[不列颠哥伦比亚省]没有做出保护栖息地的新承诺，而是继续批准伐木。显而易见的是，我们根据《濒危物种法案》下达了紧急命令来应对紧急情况 - 我们从部长和现在内阁所看到的情况与紧急响应相去甚远。”

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 03:22:02 +0800 Spotify’s new audiobook streaming could have ‘devastating effect’, says Society of Authorshttps://www.theguardian.com/books/2023/oct/11/spotify-audiobook-streaming-devastating-effect-authors
;;2023-10-11T15:40:05Z;
;
;;智能手机上显示 Spotify 徽标，屏幕上显示 Spotify
;

;作家协会 ( SoA）表示，它对 Spotify 的新有声读物供应“深感担忧”。该行业机构指出“音乐流媒体对艺术家的收入产生了毁灭性影响”，并表示担心作者可能会遭受类似的损失。

;

;“有声读物的流媒体直接与销售竞争，并且比音乐流媒体更具破坏性，因为书籍通常只被阅读一次，而音乐通常会被多次流媒体播放。”SoA 的一份声明中写道。

;

;10 月初，;书商报道;“所有主要图书出版商”已与 Spotify 达成有限的流媒体交易。自 10 月 4 日起，英国和澳大利亚的 Spotify Premium 订阅者每月可以访问多达 15 小时的有声读物内容，内容来自超过 150,000 种图书。

;

;“据我们所知据了解，尚未联系任何作者或代理人以获得此类许可的许可，也未就许可或付款条款咨询作者，”SoA 表示。 “出版合同有所不同，但我们认为，授予出版商的大多数音频许可不包括流媒体。事实上，流媒体很可能并不是在签订许多此类合同时发明的用途。”

;
;

;;相关：;;Spotify 的价格上涨对其意味着什么唱片艺术家和歌曲作者？;

;
;

;Yara Rodrigues Fowler，;今年早些时候被评为格兰塔最佳英国年轻小说家之一的她表示，在她的处女作《顽固的档案管理员》的有声读物出现在流媒体应用程序上之前，“根本没有征求过她的意见”。她的经纪人伊莫金·佩勒姆补充道：“关键问题是这笔交易完全不为人所知。无法理解这会给作者带来什么好处。”作家兼历史学家 Greg Jenner ;在推特上表示，; 他只是在 Spotify 上发现我们的两本有声读物时才了解到 Spotify 交易，我们不知道”。

;

;文学经纪人乔尼·盖勒 (Jonny Geller) 证实，在 Spotify 交易达成之前，没有人联系过他和柯蒂斯·布朗经纪公司的同事。 “这当然是不寻常的，因为音频版权是作者工作和收入的重要且不断增长的一部分，”他说。 “我们将密切关注出版商提供的优惠，以确保所提供的版税取决于每本有声读物的购买量，而不是人们可能听或不听的时间。”

;

;“我们确实这样做不想重蹈音乐产业的覆辙，”他补充道。多年来，音乐家们一直抱怨他们无法通过数字音乐版税谋生，因为据报道流媒体平台的报酬水平较低。今年早些时候;议会报告;呼吁英国政府简化创意产业的政策制定，以使该行业对英国音乐家来说更加公平。

;

;SoA 首席执行官尼古拉·所罗门 (Nicola Solomon) 表示，“事实上，所有主要出版商都签署了类似的协议Spotify 表示，这件事已经讨论了一段时间了。那么为什么没有咨询作者和经纪人呢？”

;

;“这些流媒体交易的收入将如何计算？”她接着问道。 “我们如何确保此类交易不会与销售竞争，并确保作者获得全额报酬。这对长期收益意味着什么？出版商针对盗版和不受限制的使用采取了哪些保护措施？”

;

;“我们迫切需要相关出版商与作者和代理商进行对话，而这是他们在达成这些交易之前就应该进行的。”< /p>;

;除了寻求作者和代理人对这些交易的批准外，SoA 还呼吁出版商为作者提供多种保护，包括协商“以清晰、公平的支付模式获得适当的收入份额”并确保“许可证包括防止盗版作者和叙述者的作品和声音（包括用于人工智能系统的作品和声音）的保障措施”。

;

;Pan Macmillan 表示，它“始终对销售更多我们的授权产品的机会感兴趣”出版商的一位代表表示：“当然，我们仔细审查了我们的合同，只向 Spotify 提供我们获准以流媒体有声读物形式发行的图书。” “我们对 Spotify 为有声读物开辟新受众的可能性感到兴奋。”

;

;根据企鹅兰登书屋的全球网站，英国最大的出版社对于将其作品纳入 Spotify 的目录感到“兴奋”，它将每月 15 小时的模型描述为与 Audible 等现有服务的代币模型相当，在该模型中，会员可以获得一本有声读物的一个积分。声明中写道：“我们很高兴能有这个激动人心的机会，将我们作者的作品和声音带给 Spotify 的 2.2 亿付费用户。”

;

;Spotify 商务副总裁 David Kaefer， ;本周早些时候告诉书商;，每个出版商都同意了略有不同的合同。 “我们有一个针对我们部分合作伙伴的联合模式，通常是规模稍小的合作伙伴，”他说。 “有些人，尤其是较大的提供商，想做一些不同的事情。”这种联合模式将使出版商获得 Spotify 有声读物总收入的一定比例。

;

;Spotify 尚未回应《卫报》关于直接解决 SoA 担忧的要求。

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 02:22:01 +0800 Dementia risk factors pose more danger for ethnic minorities, finds studyhttps://www.theguardian.com/society/2023/oct/11/dementia-risk-factors-pose-more-danger-for-ethnic-minorities-finds-study
;;2023-10-11T18:00:46Z;
;
;;疗养院居民的手
;

;出现痴呆症最常见的危险因素一项研究表明，对黑人和亚洲人产生更明显的影响，这促使人们呼吁加大力度解决健康不平等问题。

;

;全球患有痴呆症的成年人数量将增加近两倍，达到 1.53 亿到 2050 年。专家表示，这种疾病对每个社区、国家和大陆的未来健康和社会保健系统构成重大且迅速增长的威胁。

;

;研究人员早就知道，痴呆症的一些最大风险因素，高血压和糖尿病等在少数族裔中更为常见。

;

;新的研究表明，一些危险因素不仅在少数族裔中更为常见，而且对他们患上糖尿病的风险也有更大的影响。与白人相比，患有这种疾病。

;

;这项发表在《Plos One》杂志上的研究没有确定原因。但研究人员表示，糖尿病和肥胖等风险因素的影响似乎在某些种族群体中被“放大”。

;

;伦敦大学学院 Naaheed Mukadam 领导的团队研究了风险因素与肥胖之间的关系。使用 1997 年至 2018 年间英国 865,674 名成年人的健康数据对痴呆症进行了研究。

;

;研究小组发现，该人群中有 12.6% 患有痴呆症。大约16%是白人，8.6%是南亚人，12.1%是黑人，9.7%来自其他少数民族。

;

;他们评估了患者中与痴呆症相关的危险因素，包括肥胖、糖尿病、睡眠疾病、高血压和血脂异常——血脂失衡会导致心脏病。

;

;与白人相比，黑人患高血压的痴呆症风险更高，而南亚人患痴呆症的风险更高与睡眠障碍、糖尿病、低 HDL 胆固醇和高血压相关的风险更高。

;

;与白人患者相比，高血压对南亚人痴呆风险的影响高出 1.57 倍，高出 1.18 倍研究人员表示，在黑人中也存在这种情况。

;

;研究小组表示，他们的研究可以解释“之前发现的少数族裔群体更易患痴呆症、发病年龄更早以及诊断出痴呆症后生存期更短的发现”。

;

;作者补充道：“我们发现，一些痴呆症风险因素不仅在少数族裔群体中更常见，而且其中一些风险因素的影响甚至比白人群体更大。因此，我们需要针对种族和风险因素进行量身定制的痴呆症预防，以确保痴呆症预防的公平性。”

;

;英国阿尔茨海默氏症研究中心政策负责人戴维·托马斯 (David Thomas) 表示：“这是一个令人震惊的事实少数民族面临多种健康状况的风险增加，这影响了他们健康生活的能力。最近的研究表明，痴呆症也不例外 - 来自南亚和黑人社区的人似乎更有可能死于痴呆症，而且年龄也更轻。

;

;“这些最新发现表明了一个原因：在南亚和黑人社区中，高血压等风险因素对增加个人患痴呆症风险的影响似乎更大。

;

;“了解为什么这种影响更大很重要，因为这样做会增加个人患痴呆症的风险。”为减少这种令人心碎的情况对个人和社会的影响提供了巨大的机会。但这不仅仅是一个公共卫生问题，也是一个政治问题。我们需要一项全国性的跨政府预防战略来解决健康不平等问题。”

;

;与此同时，同样由伦敦大学学院进行的第二项研究的结果表明，患有早期阿尔茨海默病（痴呆症最常见的原因）的人，行走时难以转身。

;

;这项小型研究涉及约 100 人，发表在《当代生物学》上，发现患有早期阿尔茨海默病的人始终高估自己的转弯，并且方向感存在较大差异。

;

; p>;

;阿尔茨海默病协会的 Sian Gregory 表示，导航问题被认为是该疾病最早明显的变化之一，因此这项研究提供了“宝贵的见解”。

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 02:22:01 +0800 Two sleeping Afghan adults shot dead by SAS was ‘war crime’, inquiry hearshttps://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/oct/11/two-sleeping-afghan-adults-shot-dead-by-sas-was-war-inquiry-hears
;;2023-10-11T17:30:29Z;
;
;;一名驻阿富汗英国士兵离开镜头
;

;两名阿富汗成年人在拍摄时被枪杀公开调查获悉，2012 年 8 月，SAS 在 SAS 附近睡觉，两名儿童受重伤。

;

;在针对 SAS 在阿富汗杀害 80 名平民的公开调查中，代表受害者家属的律师表示，该事件构成英国士兵犯下的战争罪。

;

;代表曼苏尔·阿齐兹和 33 名受害者家属的理查德·赫尔默·KC 表示，24 岁的侯赛因·乌兹巴克扎伊 (Hussain Uzbakzai) 和同为 24 岁的鲁西亚·毛拉·穆罕默德·哈利姆 (Ruqqia Mullah Muhammad Haleem)当乌兹巴克扎伊的兄弟阿齐兹回到家时，“他和两个学龄前儿童睡在外面的院子里”，他们被特种空勤团成员枪杀。哥哥和嫂子”，赫尔默说。他们的孩子失踪是因为他们被紧急送往医疗机构接受治疗。

;

;阿齐兹在一段从普什图语翻译过来的短视频中简短地回答了这一问题。他在其中介绍了他的侄子伊姆兰和比拉勒，他说他们当时受了重伤，并且从那时起就一直受到创伤。

;

;“即使到今天，他们仍然对发生在我们身上的事件感到悲痛，他们很沮丧。他们想知道为什么这种事件发生在我们身上，”阿齐兹说。 “我们要求法庭倾听这些孩子的心声，伸张正义。” 调查得知，另外两名成年人也在袭击中丧生，但只从袭击中发现了一件武器，一枚手榴弹。化合物。 SAS 指挥官从未将这一事件转交给宪兵进行潜在的刑事调查。

;

;本周，由哈登-凯夫大法官主持的公开调查听取了另一项指控，称九名阿富汗男子被枪杀2011 年 2 月 7 日，在 SAS 的另一场夜间突袭中，他在睡觉时被杀——这是法庭正在审查的一系列致命突袭之一。

;

;周一，调查的律师奥利弗·格拉斯哥 KC 表示，调查的目的是对 2012 年 8 月的突袭展开具体调查，因为“年幼的儿童受伤”。

;

;但是，格拉斯哥补充说，国防部 (MoD) 或 SAS 与这次突袭有关的任何文件都没有被发布到公共领域，这意味着无法获得军方的事件版本。周二发布的国防部声明并未直接提及据称有平民被非法杀害的个别事件。

;

;诸如阿齐兹家族的证词以及主要取自 SAS 电子邮件和其他证据的证词赫尔默说，国防部自己的文件强调了指控的严重性，并证明英国精锐士兵在夜间袭击中非法杀害阿富汗平民。

;

;这是“有证据表明他们[赫尔默说：“SAS]正在进行一场谋杀活动，这不仅明显构成国内法中的犯罪行为，而且构成严重违反日内瓦公约的战争罪”。

;

;军警最近还意识到一起据赫尔默称，英国特种部队的一名现役士兵被指控“向家人透露，他在阿富汗执行任务时开枪打死了一名儿童”。

;

;但据皇家宪兵称，在赫尔默在调查前引用的一份声明称，两名潜在的平民证人拒绝提供证据，对儿童杀害事件的调查也被放弃，因为人们认为不存在起诉的现实前景。

;

;受害人家属的代表结束了为期三天的调查开场陈词，预计需要 12 至 18 个月的时间才能产生临时报告。大部分证据将在没有媒体或公众在场的情况下秘密听取，国防部只会正式承认英国特种部队参与其中，尽管人们普遍认为指的是 SAS。

;

;调查是由前国防部长本·华莱士 (Ben Wallace) 发起的，此前，多年来一直有关于 SAS 在 2010 年至 2013 年期间在阿富汗进行法外杀戮的指控，以及随后的掩盖行为，警方的调查令人沮丧。

;

;Haddon-凯夫坚称，调查决心查清事件真相，并表示英国的形象受到威胁。 “只要这些指控以某种方式仍未得到解决，就没有人会怀疑这些指控的潜在破坏性有多大，以及它们对军队声誉以及英国国际地位的腐蚀性有多大，”他说。

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 01:52:01 +0800 King Charles to acknowledge ‘painful’ past on state visit to Kenyahttps://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/oct/11/king-charles-to-acknowledge-painful-past-on-state-visit-to-kenya
;;2023-10-11T17:34:37Z;
;
;;查尔斯于 10 月 31 日至 11 月 3 日访问肯尼亚，这将是他作为国王首次访问英联邦国家
;

;查尔斯国王将在本月晚些时候进行国事访问期间承认英国和肯尼亚过去的“痛苦方面”。

;

;此次访问是应该国总统威廉·鲁托的邀请进行的，该国将庆祝12 月 12 日是其脱离英国独立 60 周年。尽管 20 世纪 50 年代初的起义留下了暴力殖民遗产，导致了从 1952 年到 1960 年的“紧急状态”时期，但两国近年来仍保持着密切关系。

;

;基库尤部落的一些成员对英国统治者和在肯尼亚耕种土地的欧洲定居者感到不满，以及缺乏政治代表权，从而加剧了 Mau Mau 武装运动。

;

;

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 01:22:01 +0800 Court finds police in France often use racial profiling in identity checkshttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/11/court-police-france-racial-profiling-identity-checks-discriminatory
;;2023-10-11T16:49:30Z;
;
;;人们在阿维尼翁游行，巴黎郊外的一个交通站一名青少年被枪杀，全国范围内的抗议活动仍在继续，反对警察暴力.
;

;法国最高行政法院已承认;discriminatory police identity checks; based on racial profiling exist in France and are not isolated cases, but said it could not change political policy on the issue.

;

;In a class action against the French state, six French and international organisations including Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch and the Open Society Justice Initiative had asked for French authorities to be found at fault for failing to prevent the widespread use of ;racial profiling;.

;

;They had asked the court to impose measures to make France end the practise, arguing that non-white people across France, notably young men perceived to be black or north African backgrounds, are routinely singled out and stopped in the street, asked for identity papers and frisked without explanation, often several times a day and from as young as 10 or 11 years old.

;

;The court – the Conseil d'État – stopped short of calling the issue systemic, but did say such checks were “not limited to isolated cases”.

;

;Significantly, it also said the practice amounted to “discrimination for the people who have had an identity check on the basis of physical characteristics associated with their real or perceived origin ”. But added that it did not have the jurisdiction to force a change in political policy.

;

;France has experienced widespread protests and unrest over the ;police shooting of Nahel;, a 17-year-old boy of Algerian descent, at a traffic stop outside Paris in June. During the protests over his death, teenagers and young people of black and north African origin said they faced widespread discrimination, and were often stopped several times a day by police for identity checks without explanation.

;

;Maïté De Rue, a senior lawyer at the Open Society Justice Initiative who is involved in the case, said: “The decision of the state council is extremely disappointing. It recognised that ethnic profiling is a serious and pervasive problem in France. But it missed the historic opportunity to order the French authorities to take measures to to end this racial discrimination, in compliance with their international obligations.”

;

;Various organisations involved in the case said it was symbolic that the court had recognised that the discrimination existed and was not just a question of isolated incidents. But they said the ruling had not gone far enough.

;

;;Bénédicte Jeannerod; of Human Rights Watch said she hoped this would stop what she called the “posture of denial” of successive governments over the existence of the problem of racial profiling in France.

;

;Issa Coulibaly, the head of Pazapas, a local youth group based in the Paris suburb of Belleville, who was part of the legal action, said the court had “failed to understand the violence and exclusion generated by these police practices. They failed to grasp the historic opportunity to improve the daily lives of millions of their fellow citizens, particularly those perceived as black and north African.”

;

;He said: “It was a missed opportunity. The court had the opportunity to change the daily reality of people subjected to this. They considered they couldn't do it. And that raises a lot of questions. How will that be seen by people affected by racial profiling?”

;

;He said people would once again feel that the problem was being minimised.

;

;Coulibaly said he had turned to the court because politics and politicians had failed to address the problem for 40 years. “And today the court is sending us back to politics, but for decades the political class has failed to acted on this,” he said.

;

;In a separate ruling, the court said officers must clearly display their identification number badge, which campaigners hope would improve investigations into alleged police violence

;

;Police officers' number badge, known as a RIO, should be made bigger so it is readable, especially when they intervene in large gatherings, the court said. Although wearing the RIO has been a legal obligation since 2013, it is often too small, not clearly displayed or completely hidden, rights organisations had told the court.

;

;Lawyers said this was a “very good decision” but they said that police officers' number badges would not prevent discriminatory identity checks.

;

;In 2017, the French rights ombudsman estimated that men perceived to be black or north African were ;20 times more likely; than others to be stopped by police for identity checks.

;

;France's interior minister, Gérald Darmanin, told a parliamentary commission in July: “It's false to say there is systemic racism in the national police.”

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 01:22:01 +0800 Demonstration in Oslo seeks removal of windfarms in Indigenous regionhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/11/demonstration-in-oslo-seeks-removal-of-windfarms-in-indigenous-region
;;2023-10-11T16:43:42Z;
;
;;Spokesperson for the Fosen campaign Ella Marie Hætta Isaksen
;

;Hundreds of Indigenous and environmental campaigners have blocked a main thoroughfare in Oslo to demand the demolition of two windfarms that have been described by the Norwegian government as a “violation of human rights”.

;

;The Wednesday protest traces its roots to a ;landmark 2021; decision by Norway's supreme court that found 151 wind turbines in the western region of Fosen had trampled on the rights of Sámi reindeer herders by encroaching on their pastures.

;

;While the court said the turbines' expropriation and operating permits were invalid, it did not specify what should be done with the infrastructure.

;

;As a result the 151 turbines continue to operate, making up part of Europe's largest onshore windfarm, even as Sámi activists repeatedly call for their removal.

;

;“In this case there really isn't an acceptable compromise,” said Sámi activist Ella Marie Hætta Isaksen. “It's really an absurd situation. Today on the second year anniversary of the verdict, we have to drop everything and put our everyday lives on hold because we need to make sure that our own government is following its law.”

; ;

;The government's reluctance to remove the turbines was “completely devastating”, she said. “It truly is a painful case.

;

;It feels like the government is really strategically removing the reindeer rearing culture,” she continued. “And it really scares a lot of young people because for us, our culture is everything. It really feels like we are nothing without our lands or our reindeer.”

;

;Hætta Isaksen was among the hundreds of people, some waving Sámi flags and wearing the traditional gákti, who took to Oslo's streets early on Wednesday, setting up several Sámi tents known as ;laavu;.

;

;Later she joined a dozen or so people who occupied a hall in the country's parliament building, singing joik, the traditional Sami chants.

;

;It was the latest in a series of protests calling for the turbines to be taken down that have brought together environmentalists and Sámi since the court decision.

;

;At a protest earlier this year Greta Thunberg, who is due to join the protest on Thursday, was ;among those detained;.

;

;At the time, the climate activist explained why she and others had rallied behind the Sámi. “We can't use the so-called climate transition as a cover for colonialism,” Thunberg told ;broadcaster TV2.; “A climate transition that violates human rights is not a climate transition worthy of the name.”

; ;

;The March protest was ;credited; for pushing the government to acknowledge the harm that turbines had done to the Sámi community. “I have apologised on behalf of the government to the reindeer herding districts for the fact that the permits constituted a violation of human rights,” the minister of petroleum and energy, Terje Aasland, ;told a news conference.;

;

;Even so, the government has so far resisted calls to tear down the turbines and restore the lands where dozens of kilometres of roads were built. In a recent social media post Aasland appeared to rule out the possibility entirely, writing that “the destruction of all wind turbines was excluded”, according to AFP.

;

;Instead, the government has thrown its weight behind a mediation process between the wind farms, which can ;reportedly power; 100,000 Norwegian homes, and the herders who continue to insist that the only solution is to take down the turbines.

;

;The outcome of the conflict is being watched closely across Norway, as it could signal the fate of other projects under development, from mines to power lines, in the vast lands traditionally used by the Sámi.

; ;

;Gina Gylver, the head of the Norwegian branch of the environment organisation Young Friends of the Earth, welcomed the idea that the case could set a precedent. “It is possible to find solutions that also take into consideration Indigenous rights,” she said. “I think it is important for politicians to note that industry can be moved but Indigenous people cannot.”

;

;Others pointed to the years-long dispute as a cautionary tale, with Ketan Joshi, the author of Windfall: Unlocking a fossil free future, describing it as the “obvious outcome of extremely poorly thought-out wind power growth.”

;

;In an email he added: “Norway perfectly illustrates that fast but unjust clean energy development ultimately leads to a much slower pace of change than a steady, sustainable and community-focused mode of development.”

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 00:52:02 +0800 Monkey survives for two years with pig kidney in ‘extraordinary milestone’https://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/oct/11/monkey-survives-two-years-with-pig-kidney-transplant
;;2023-10-11T15:25:24Z;
;
;;A macaque monkey
;

;Researchers have claimed a major step forward in the field of organ transplantation after a monkey survived for more than two years with a genetically engineered pig kidney.

;

;The work is the latest to emerge from the US biotech company eGenesis and Harvard Medical School, where scientists see genetically altered pigs as a potential solution to the global shortage of donors for patients with organ failure.

;

;Dr Michael Curtis, the chief executive of eGenesis, said the “extraordinary milestone” provided hope for the approach and “may pave the way for better outcomes for countless individuals in need of lifesaving organ transplants”.

;

;Scientists have spent decades working out whether animal organs could ever work properly and safely in humans without them being rejected by the patient's immune system, but the challenges have proved immense.

;

;For the latest trial, researchers used a ;gene-editing tool called Crispr; to alter genes in Yucatan miniature pigs before transplanting their kidneys into macaques. The modifications altered genes to prevent organ rejection and remove pig viruses that could potentially be activated in recipients.

;

;Writing in the ;journal Nature;, the scientists describe how 21 monkeys fared after their kidneys were removed and a single genetically modified pig kidney was implanted. Monkeys typically survived only 24 days when the kidneys were edited to disable three genes that trigger immune rejection. But when the scientists added seven human genes that reduce blood clotting, inflammation and other immune reactions, the monkeys survived seven times longer, typically for 176 days.

;

;When combined with treatment to suppress the immune system, the researchers report that one monkey survived for more than two years – 758 days – with the transplanted organ.

;

;Curtis said the long-term survival of at least some of the monkeys had put eGenesis on course to satisfy the US Food and Drug Administration requirement to see at least 12 months' survival in animals before the team can launch a clinical trial in humans.

;

;“We are well on our way there,” Curtis said. “There simply aren't enough kidneys to go around. In our opinion it's the only near-term viable solution.”

;

;The team uses Yucatan miniature pigs as donors because at maturity their kidneys are roughly the same size of those in the adult human. In the monkey trial, the kidneys were transplanted at two to three months when the organs were much smaller.

;

;Prof Tatsuo Kawai, an author on the study at Harvard Medical School, said the scientists expected the modified pig organs to perform better in humans than monkeys because “they are a better match”.

;

;Two humans have so far received pig heart transplants. The first, ;David Bennett;, died two months after surgery in 2022. The second, 58-year-old Lawrence Faucette, who had end-stage heart disease, received a new heart on 20 September this year and is in recovery.

;

;Prof Muhammad Mohiuddin, at the University of Maryland School of Medicine, who was involved in the ;pioneering heart transplants;, said genetically modified pig organs should move into human trials.

;

;“It is time for clinical translation of this vital technology, which has the potential to save lives that would otherwise be lost to the shortage of human organs,” he wrote in an accompanying editorial.

;

;“There is still much to be learned from non-human primate preclinical models. But it will be clinical trials, enrolling people who have been excluded from all other hope of treatment, that will truly further our understanding of this remarkable procedure, and help to realise the potential of this technology.”

;

;Prof Dusko Ilic, at King's College London, called the work a “groundbreaking achievement”, but said: “There is still a long way to go before this strategy could be used in clinical trials.”

; Wed, 11 Oct 2023 23:52:01 +0800 Afterglow of cataclysmic collision between two planets seen for first timehttps://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/oct/11/afterglow-cataclysmic-collision-between-two-planets-seen-for-first-time
;;2023-10-11T15:00:42Z;
;
;;An artist's impression of the huge, glowing planetary body produced by a planetary collision.
;

;The warm afterglow of a worlds-shattering collision between two massive planets has been seen for the first time after astronomers trained their telescopes on a distant sun-like star.

;

;The cataclysmic event is believed to have destroyed a pair of ice giant planets that slammed into one another to produce a shower of debris and a hot, spinning object potentially hundreds of times the size of Earth.

;

;“It would be very spectacular,” said Dr Matthew Kenworthy, a co-lead author on the study at the Leiden Observatory in the Netherlands. “The energy of the collision would turn the remnant into something resembling a star, fainter than the main star in the system but about seven times larger in size, visible all through the rest of the stellar system.”

;

;The discovery came about after an amateur astronomer responded to a social media post from Kenworthy about a star known as ASASSN-21qj. Kenworthy was looking for shadows cast by giant rings around planets as they cross the face of their parent star. ASASSN-21qj, which lies 1,800 light years from Earth, piqued his interest because in December 2021 it suddenly and inexplicably dimmed.

;

;On reading the post, Arttu Sainio, ;a volunteer citizen scientist for Nasa;, checked past observations of the star by Nasa's Neowise mission, an infrared space telescope. He found that 900 days before the star dimmed, Neowise saw a steady and sustained brightening of infrared light from the same location.

; ;

;“I was looking for something completely different,” Kenworthy said. “The infrared brightening told us something unusual had happened in the neighbourhood of this star, and so it took us down this new path.”

;

;After a detailed analysis of the observations, the astronomers concluded that the blast of infrared radiation came from a hot new object or “synestia” created by the collision of two planets nearly as large as Neptune. Based on the infrared readings, the vast spinning object had a temperature of more than 700C for about three years. It will eventually cool and form a new planet around the star.

;

;According to details ;published in Nature;, the star began to dim about 2.5 years after the afterglow began as a massive cloud of fine impact debris drifted across the face of the star.

;

;“It's the first time we've seen the afterglow from such an event,” said Simon Lock, another co-lead author at the University of Bristol. “We've seen debris and discs before, but we have never seen the afterglow of the planetary body that's produced.”

;

;Astronomers are now keen to follow up the observations to confirm what they suspect has unfolded. If the dust cloud continues to orbit the star, then in about five to 10 years the cloud will have moved to one side of the star and astronomers should see the star's light reflected from the dust with the largest ground-based telescopes, Kenworthy said.

;

;It may also be possible for the James Webb Space Telescope to detect infrared radiation from the dust and the new planet created in the collision.
